segment.source: This article provides an overview of Bluetooth RFCOMM in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, along with example code on how to send or receive a file..
segment.target: This article provides an overview of Bluetooth RFCOMM in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, along with example code on how to send or receive a file..

segment.source: Overview
segment.target: Overview

segment.source: The APIs in the Windows.Devices.Bluetooth.Rfcomm namespace build on existing patterns for Windows.Devices, including enumeration and instantiation.
segment.target: The APIs in the Windows.Devices.Bluetooth.Rfcomm namespace build on existing patterns for Windows.Devices, including enumeration and instantiation.

segment.source: Data reading and writing is designed to take advantage of established data stream patterns and objects in Windows.Storage.Streams.
segment.target: Data reading and writing is designed to take advantage of established data stream patterns and objects in Windows.Storage.Streams.

segment.source: Session Description Protocol (SDP) attributes have a value and an expected type.
segment.target: Session Description Protocol (SDP) attributes have a value and an expected type.

segment.source: However, some common devices have faulty implementations of SDP attributes where the value is not of the expected type.
segment.target: However, some common devices have faulty implementations of SDP attributes where the value is not of the expected type.

segment.source: Additionally, many usages of RFCOMM do not require additional SDP attributes at all.
segment.target: Additionally, many usages of RFCOMM do not require additional SDP attributes at all.

segment.source: For these reasons, this API offers access to the unparsed SDP data, from which developers can obtain the information they need.
segment.target: For these reasons, this API offers access to the unparsed SDP data, from which developers can obtain the information they need.

segment.source: The RFCOMM APIs use the concept of service identifiers.
segment.target: The RFCOMM APIs use the concept of service identifiers.

segment.source: Although a service identifier is simply a 128-bit GUID, it is also commonly specified as either a 16- or 32-bit integer.
segment.target: Although a service identifier is simply a 128-bit GUID, it is also commonly specified as either a 16- or 32-bit integer.

segment.source: The RFCOMM API offers a wrapper for service identifiers that allows them be specified and consumed as 128-bit GUIDs as well as 32-bit integers but does not offer 16-bit integers.
segment.target: The RFCOMM API offers a wrapper for service identifiers that allows them be specified and consumed as 128-bit GUIDs as well as 32-bit integers but does not offer 16-bit integers.

segment.source: This is not an issue for the API because languages will automatically upsize to a 32-bit integer and the identifier can still be correctly generated.
segment.target: This is not an issue for the API because languages will automatically upsize to a 32-bit integer and the identifier can still be correctly generated.

segment.source: Apps can perform multi-step device operations in a background task so that they can run to completion even if the app is moved to the background and suspended.
segment.target: Apps can perform multi-step device operations in a background task so that they can run to completion even if the app is moved to the background and suspended.

segment.source: This allows for reliable device servicing such as changes to persistent settings or firmware, and content synchronization, without requiring the user to sit and watch a progress bar.
segment.target: This allows for reliable device servicing such as changes to persistent settings or firmware, and content synchronization, without requiring the user to sit and watch a progress bar.

segment.source: Use the DeviceServicingTrigger for device servicing and the DeviceUseTrigger for content synchronization.
segment.target: Use the DeviceServicingTrigger for device servicing and the DeviceUseTrigger for content synchronization.

segment.source: Note that these background tasks constrain the amount of time the app can run in the background, and are not intended to allow indefinite operation or infinite synchronization.
segment.target: Note that these background tasks constrain the amount of time the app can run in the background, and are not intended to allow indefinite operation or infinite synchronization.

segment.source: Send a file as a client
segment.target: Send a file as a client

segment.source: When sending a file, the most basic scenario is to connect to a paired device based on a desired service.
segment.target: When sending a file, the most basic scenario is to connect to a paired device based on a desired service.

segment.source: This involves the following steps:
segment.target: This involves the following steps:

segment.source: Use the RfcommDeviceService.GetDeviceSelector\* functions to help generate an AQS query that can be used to enumerated paired device instances of the desired service.
segment.target: Use the RfcommDeviceService.GetDeviceSelector\* functions to help generate an AQS query that can be used to enumerated paired device instances of the desired service.

segment.source: Pick an enumerated device, create an RfcommDeviceService, and read the SDP attributes as needed (using established data helpers to parse the attribute's data).
segment.target: Pick an enumerated device, create an RfcommDeviceService, and read the SDP attributes as needed (using established data helpers to parse the attribute's data).

segment.source: Create a socket and use the RfcommDeviceService.ConnectionHostName and RfcommDeviceService.ConnectionServiceName properties to StreamSocket.ConnectAsync to the remote device service with the appropriate parameters.
segment.target: Create a socket and use the RfcommDeviceService.ConnectionHostName and RfcommDeviceService.ConnectionServiceName properties to StreamSocket.ConnectAsync to the remote device service with the appropriate parameters.

segment.source: Follow established data stream patterns to read chunks of data from the file and send it on the socket's StreamSocket.OutputStream to the device.
segment.target: Follow established data stream patterns to read chunks of data from the file and send it on the socket's StreamSocket.OutputStream to the device.

segment.source: Receive File as a Server
segment.target: Receive File as a Server

segment.source: Another common RFCOMM App scenario is to host a service on the PC and expose it for other devices.
segment.target: Another common RFCOMM App scenario is to host a service on the PC and expose it for other devices.

segment.source: Create a RfcommServiceProvider to advertise the desired service.
segment.target: Create a RfcommServiceProvider to advertise the desired service.

segment.source: Set the SDP attributes as needed (using established data helpers to generate the attribute’s Data) and starts advertising the SDP records for other devices to retrieve.
segment.target: Set the SDP attributes as needed (using established data helpers to generate the attribute’s Data) and starts advertising the SDP records for other devices to retrieve.

segment.source: To connect to a client device, create a socket listener to start listening for incoming connection requests.
segment.target: To connect to a client device, create a socket listener to start listening for incoming connection requests.

segment.source: When a connection is received, store the connected socket for later processing.
segment.target: When a connection is received, store the connected socket for later processing.

segment.source: Follow established data stream patterns to read chunks of data from the socket's InputStream and save it to a file.
segment.target: Follow established data stream patterns to read chunks of data from the socket's InputStream and save it to a file.
